doc.title: US Daily: August GSAI: Sticky Near Sity (endels)
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-01/US Daily_ August GSAI_ Sticky Near Sixty (Rindels)_2025-09-01

passages.text: The Goldman Sachs Analyst Index (GSAI) was roughly unchanged for a second consecutive month, ticking up by 0.5pt to 59.0 in August. The composition was mixed- to- weak, as the shipments component increased (+2.4pt to 62.5) while the new orders (- 5.3pt to 50.4) and employment (- 3.4pt to 41.2) components both declined.

Other business activity surveys were mixed but increased on net in August. Our manufacturing survey tracker (+1.2pt to 51.9) and our nonmanufacturing survey tracker (+0.9pt to 54.2) both increased, and the employment components of business surveys were roughly unchanged at low levels. In the special questions in this month's Dallas Fed surveys, firms indicated that tariffs have raised input costs and selling prices but lowered employment, production, and profit margins this year. Further, 80% of firms reported that they were passing tariff cost increases on to consumers, though firms appeared to be passing through slightly less of the tariff costs over a slightly longer period of time on net than they expected to in April.

In this month's GSAI special questions, surveyed analysts indicated that concerns about a weaker economic outlook, policy uncertainty, higher input costs, and artificial intelligence (AI) adoption led companies to slow their pace of hiring relative to the beginning of the year. One third of surveyed analysts reported that companies slowed their pace of hiring relative to the beginning of the year, while only 8% said that companies are now hiring at a faster pace.

The Goldman Sachs Analyst Index (GSAI) was roughly unchanged for a second consecutive month, ticking up by 0.5pt to 59.0 in August (Exhibit 1). The composition was mixed- to- weak, as the shipments component increased \((+2.4pt\) to 62.5) while the new orders (- 5.3pt to 50.4) and employment (- 3.4pt to 41.2) components both declined.

The inventories component increased again \((+3.1pt\) to 78.3) following a 35.4pt increase in July, while the exports component declined (- 12.5pt to 50.0). The orders less inventories gap (- 27.9pt to - 8.4) declined.
The GSAI's materials prices \((+12.6pt\) to 81.3), output prices \((+8.8pt\) to 65.7), and wages \((+3.6pt\) to 63.6) components all increased.
Exhibit 1: The GSAI Ticked Up in August
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Institute for Supply Management

Other business activity surveys were mixed but increased on net in August. Our manufacturing survey tracker \((+1.2pt\) to 51.9) and our nonmanufacturing survey tracker \((+0.9pt\) to 54.2) both increased. The employment components of business surveys were roughly unchanged and remained in contractionary territory this month. The employment component of our manufacturing survey tracker edged up by 0.2pt to 49.0, and the employment component of our services survey tracker decreased by 0.5pt to 48.4 in August.
Exhibit 2: Business Activity Surveys Were Mixed but Increased on Net in August
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Federal Reserve, Markit

In the special questions in this month's Dallas Fed surveys, firms indicated that tariffs have raised input costs and selling prices but lowered employment, production, and profit margins this year. \(47\%\) of firms reported that higher tariffs increased input costs on net this year, somewhat below the \(65\%\) of firms that expected the net effect of higher tariffs to increase input costs when the question was last asked in April (left panel of Exhibit 3). \(21\%\) of firms reported that they had increased selling prices this year in response to tariffs, below the \(37\%\) that expected to do so in April. Firms reported that tariffs have weighed on other aspects of their business, including employment, investment plans, revenue, their company outlook, and profit margins. \(10\%\) of firms reported that profit margins declined significantly this year, slightly below the \(16\%\) that expected margins to decline significantly in the April survey. While \(11\%\) of firms reported that employment declined this year as a result of tariffs, \(88\%\) reported that tariffs have had no impact on employment.

\(80\%\) of firms reported that they were passing cost increases from tariffs on to consumers (right panel of Exhibit 3). Among those respondents, \(21\%\) reported that they have already passed through the full cost of the tariffs to customers, slightly below the \(25\%\) that expected to do so when the question was asked in April (left panel of Exhibit 4). \(36\%\) of firms have passed through most of the cost of the tariffs to consumers (vs. \(30\%\) of firms who expected to do so when the question was last asked in April) and \(43\%\) of firms have passed through some of the cost of the tariffs (vs. \(44\%\) in April). The share of firms that passed through tariff cost increases to customers immediately upon announcement of the policy ( \(16\%\) ) was lower than the share that expected to do so in April ( \(22\%\) ). On net, firms appeared to have extended their timelines for passing through tariff cost increases, as the share of firms planning to pass through cost increases within a month, within 1- 3 months, and within 4- 6 months all increased relative to the April survey (right panel of Exhibit 4).
Exhibit 3: Firms in the Dallas Fed Surveys Reported That Tariffs Raised Input Costs and Lowered Profit Margins This Year; Many Firms Are Passing Through Tariff-Driven Cost Increases to Customers
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Federal Reserve
Exhibit 4: Firms Appear to Have Extended Their Timelines for Passing Through Tariff Cost Increases to Consumers
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Federal Reserve

In this month's GSAI special questions, surveyed analysts indicated that concerns about a weaker economic outlook, policy uncertainty, higher input costs, and artificial intelligence (AI) adoption led companies to slow their pace of hiring relative to the beginning of the year. One third of surveyed analysts reported that companies slowed their pace of hiring relative to the beginning of the year, while only \(8\%\) said that companies are now hiring at a faster pace (Exhibit 5). Among those who reported that companies had become more cautious about hiring, \(75\%\) and \(50\%\) reported that policy uncertainty and concerns about a weaker economic outlook, respectively, led companies to slow their pace of hiring.

\(58\%\) of surveyed analysts reported that the companies they cover were hiring at about the same pace as at the beginning of the year, though a few analysts, including those who cover digital advertising companies, reported that while the overall pace of hiring remained roughly the same, hiring was concentrated in Al- related positions and companies were pausing hiring or even reducing headcount for non- Al- related job functions.
Exhibit 5: One Third of Surveyed Analysts Reported That the Companies They Cover Slowed Their Pace of Hiring Relative to the Start of the Year
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

As usual, we provide a detailed table of the GSAI (Exhibit 6). We construct the headline GSAI using the following weights: \(30\%\) for new orders, \(25\%\) for sales/shipments, \(20\%\) for employment, \(15\%\) for materials prices, and \(10\%\) for inventories. These weights parallel the Institute for Supply Management's pre- 2008 practice, substituting our materials prices index for their supplier deliveries index. The GSAI includes services as well as manufacturing Industries. As with the ISM indexes, a reading above 50 is intended to signal growth while an index level below 50 signals contraction. However, our analysis suggests that a GSAI of 50 appears more consistent with trend growth than with no growth. Survey responses were collected from August 20 - August 29.
Exhibit 6:Goldman Sachs Analyst Index,August 2025
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Institute for Supply Management

We, Jan Hatzius, Alec Phillips, David Mericle, Ronnie Walker, Manuel Abecasis, Elsie Peng and Jessica Rindels, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views, which have not been influenced by considerations of the firm's business or client relationships.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.

Have the Companies You Cover Changed Their Pace of Hiring Relative to the Start of the Year?

labels: Roughly the same pace of hiring

figures.title: Expected Impact of Higher Tariffs on [...] Diffusion Index

numerical_data.context: costs and selling prices but lowered employment, production, and profit margins this year. Further, 80% of firms reported that they were passing tariff cost increases on to consumers, though firms app
ported that companies slowed their pace of hiring relative to the beginning of the year, while only 8% said that companies are now hiring at a faster pace.
